intro: Campium cuspidatum, commonly known as the narrow-leafed tansy, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to Europe and parts of Asia. It belongs to the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads and opposite leaves. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, with narrow, lance-shaped leaves that are often covered in fine hairs. Its yellow flowers appear in late summer, forming small clusters at the ends of the stems. Campium cuspidatum is often found in disturbed soils and open areas, and it has been used historically in traditional medicine.
